column18: 07/05/2005: An Algerian military helicopter was shot down over Mali by an Islamic extremist group, but there were no reports of casualties or damage. The Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat (GSPC) was believed to have been responsible for the attack.
column58: Salafist Group for Preaching and Fighting (GSPC)
column108: A helicopter was damaged in this attack.
column126: �GSPC Shoots Down Algerian Chopper in Mali,� Panafrican News Agency Daily Newswire, July 5, 2005.

column18: 05/12/2007:  Ten people were killed in an attack in Tinzaouatene, northeast Mali, by former Tuareg rebel Ibrahima Bahanga.  The attack occurred in the city of Tinzaouatene.  Eight rebels were killed in the attack.  The weapons used were not described in the report. A claim of responsibility was received, however the details of the claim were not reported.
column126: \\"\"At least ten killed in rebel attack on northern town"
column130: Mali. The outcome of this incident was unknown."
column238: �Mali: Tuareg Rebels Kidnap 15 Soldiers in East� AFP.  August 27, 2007.

column18: 08/28/2007: A Mali military convoy was ambushed in Abebara, Mali. Two trucks were stolen. The perpetrators, casualties, and number of possible kidnapping victims were unknown for this incident.
column108: Two trucks were taken in this attack.
column125: The perpetrators were suspected to have kidnapped several soldiers but the number was unknown.
column126: �Milan army convoy attacked in north� Radio France Internationale.  August 28, 2007.

column18: 08/31/2007: A mine explosion in Tinzawaten, Mali killed ten people in injured several others. The perpetrator(s) were unidentified and there were no media accounts of any group claiming responsibility for the attack.
column126: �Mine explodes in northern Mali killing 10, injuring several others� OSC Summary.  August 31, 2007.

column18: 09/12/2007: Rebels led by Ibrahima Bahanga fired small arms at a U.S. Air Force c-130 Hercules transport.  The plane was carrying  food packages to Malian troops battling insurgents in Ti-n-Zaoutene, Algeria.  Minimal damage was reported and no group claimed responsibility.
column126: Terrorism, 2005-2007: A Chronology  (Westport, CT: Praeger Security International)

column17: The incident occurred at Adrar des Ifoghas Mountains
column18: 03/20/2008:  Three soldiers were killed when their mine-clearing truck hit a landmine planted by suspected Tuareg rebels in the Adrar des Iforas region of Mali.
